headline.main: LIFE AT THE POLES.; DISCOVERY OF A NORTHWEST PASSAGE. Three Years in the Polar Ice. OFFICIAL DISPATCHES OF CAPTAIN M'CLURE. CONTINUED FROM DAILY TIMES OF NOV. 12.

docs.lead_paragraph: We continue to-day our publication of Capt. M'CLURE'S dispatches: HER MAJESTY'S DISCOVERY-SUIT INVESTIGATOR, off Cape Bathurst, Polar Sea Aug 39, 1850, in lut 70?? 28' N., long 128?? 33' W. SIR: In accordance with the intention expressed at the conclusion of my last letter. I proceeded in the first whale boat, accomoanted by Dr. ARMSTRONG and Mr. MIERTSCHING, followed by Lieut. CRESSWELL and a party of officers in a cutter, bringing a variety of presents.

headline.main: LIFE AT THE POLES.; DISCOVERY OF A NORTHWEST PASSAGE. Three Years in the Polar Ice. OFFICIAL DISPATCHES OF CAPTAIN M'CLURE,

docs.lead_paragraph: The following are the official dispatches of Capt. McCLURE, of the British ship Investigator, which has succeeded in discovering the Northwest passage, to the British Admiralty. We shall continue their publication as rapidly as possible until their completion:

headline.main: THE NORTH-WEST PASSAGE.; TRACK OF THE BRITISH SHIP INVESTIGATOR, CAPT. McCLURE. FROM A CHART JUST ISSUED BY THE BRITISH ADMIRALTY. Discovery of a Northwest Passage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Very general interest has been excited by the announcement, lately received in England, that the fact of the Northwest Passage, from the Atlantic to the Pacific Oceans, has been established.
docs.snippet: Very general interest has been excited by the announcement, lately received in England, that the fact of the Northwest Passage, from the Atlantic to the Pacific Oceans, has been established.

headline.main: THE UPPER MISSOURI.; From the Selkirk Settlement.

docs.lead_paragraph: I have not written for some weeks, because nothing of any interest has been received here by myself or others from the country westward. This morning, however, I am in receipt of letters from the Upper Missouri and Pembina, in the Selkirk Settlement.
docs.snippet: I have not written for some weeks, because nothing of any interest has been received here by myself or others from the country westward. This morning, however, I am in receipt of letters from the Upper Missouri and Pembina, in the Selkirk Settlement.

byline.original: CORRESPONDENCE OF THE NEW-YORK DAILY TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: " See Naples and then die," say the Italians in their enthusiasm for the city bathed by a sea, frequently agitated by cold northerly winds, and perfumed by some meagre orange trees, whose petals are from time to time withered by frost.
docs.snippet: " See Naples and then die," say the Italians in their enthusiasm for the city bathed by a sea, frequently agitated by cold northerly winds, and perfumed by some meagre orange trees, whose petals are from time to time withered by frost.

docs.lead_paragraph: The "Independent Opposition Line's" steamer America, D. C. MITCHELL commanding, from Aspinwall, N. G., with 250 passengers, to E. MILLS, arrived at this port at an early hour this morning. The America left Aspinwall on Tuesday, Nov. 1, at 12 o'clock, and arrived at Kingston, Ja., after a run of 53 hours.
